comment.author: 62508825@N00
comment._content: www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=43959825 shows photo of headstone and confirms info above and gives Army Service Corps (ASC) as his service (received the Royal prefix in late 1918). FreeBMD - likely record - birth reg. 4th qr 1880 in Chelsea - which would make him aged 37 at the time of his death.

comment.author: 47079330@N03
comment._content: From www.findmypast.co.uk 1891 census 30 Alderville Road Fulham Frederick ADAMSON H M M 34 Clerk born Stoke on Trent Frances S. " W M F 28 born Hants Yateley Frederick J. " S M 10 born London Chelsea Thomas " Brother S M 30 born Stoke on Trent

comment.author: 47079330@N03
comment._content: His WWI pension records can be found on www.ancestry.co.uk Enlisted 30.1.1915 Address 16 Camden Street London Next of kin given as Mr N. (or W.?) GOMAN of 25 Horden Road Fulham, uncle. Frederick's occupation Baker. Marital status - Unmarried Served in 29 Field Bakery Discharged medically unfit. Medical board 19.9.1916. Tubercle of lung. Originated May 1916 Egypt. First had dysentery in Gallipoli. Reported sick in May 1916 with bronchitis. Negative family history except mother died of lung trouble and alcoholism. His sickness was put down as a result of active service strain and exposure to infection. Not permanent. Duration 12 months. He under went treatment in Brompton Sanatorium in 1917. He had moved to 68 Penge Road, South Norwood by Oct 1917 14 pages of his WWI Army service records are on www.ancestry.co.uk as well. Description when left army after serving 1 year 248 days:- Height 5' 81/2" Age 35 years, 319 days Eyes hazel, hair brown.
